abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Rural Poverty
            Alleviation Project for the State of Ceara is rated as
            satisfactory, sustainability as likely, institutional
            development impact as substantial, Bank performance as
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance as satisfactory. The
            lessons of this project include: Community Driven
            Development projects can successfully support decentralize
            resource allocation and create social capital in poor rural
            areas. The equitable graduation of communities who have
            accumulated sufficient assets and organizational capacity to
            access mainstream financing and other services, is expected
            to be an important product of this more integrated approach
            to Municipal Community Scheme Council roles/activities.
            Decentralization of fiscal and investment decision-making
            and implementation to the state and local levels ensures
            administrative efficiency and superior results.
            Participation by beneficiaries in the selection, financing,
            execution, and organization and management of subprojects
            ensures that investments meet genuine community needs.
            Poverty targeting mechanisms that are simple, verifiable and
            based on objective criteria foster transparency, minimize
            political interference in project resource allocation and
            ensure that project resources reach the poorest. Supervision
            remains an indispensable determinant of success and
            sustainability. Dissemination of "best practice"
            can speed learning and reward innovation.
